Python bivittatus.description: Large constrictor commonly called Burmese python; kills by constriction, not venom.
identification_tips: Non-venomous head shape, no raised hood
recommended_actions: Do not provoke or corner it
Allow it to move away or contact local wildlife rescue
donts: Do not attempt to catch or handle
Do not poke or throw objects at it
Do not separate from young if found with them
first_aid: If bitten: wash wound with soap and water
Seek medical attention if puncture wounds are severe or show infection
Python bivittatus.emergency: If severe injury occurs (deep bites, bleeding), seek medical care.
Python bivittatus.fallback_protocol: If model confidence is low → keep distance, treat incident as potentially dangerous, call local authorities/wildlife rescue.

Python molurus.description: Indian/Burmese type python complex; large constrictor similar to P. bivittatus.
recommended_actions: Notify wildlife control if in inhabited area
first_aid: Control bleeding with direct pressure if needed
Python molurus.emergency: Seek medical attention if bleeding is severe or bite is deep.
Python molurus.fallback_protocol: If confidence < threshold → assume potential hazard, keep safe distance, call help.

Malayopython reticulatus.description: Reticulated python: very large constrictor with distinctive reticulated pattern.
recommended_actions: Contact local wildlife services for removal
donts: Do not try to capture or kill
Don't crowd or block its escape route
first_aid: For any bite: wash, apply dressing
Consult healthcare provider for wound care
Malayopython reticulatus.emergency: Seek urgent care for deep puncture wounds or severe bleeding.
Malayopython reticulatus.fallback_protocol: If uncertain → keep distance and call authorities; treat situation as potentially hazardous.

Naja kaouthia.description: Monocled cobra — medically significant neurotoxic venom; regional species in Myanmar.
recommended_actions: Do not provoke or attempt to handle
Call emergency services immediately if bite occurs
donts: Do not try to capture, kill, or approach the snake
Do not apply tourniquets or cut the wound
Do not try to suck out venom
first_aid: Keep the patient calm and still
Immobilize the bitten limb with a splint
Remove constricting jewelry or clothing near bite site
Naja kaouthia.emergency: Seek immediate professional medical care; antivenom may be required.
Naja kaouthia.fallback_protocol: If model confidence is low → assume venomous and follow emergency protocol above.

Naja mandalayensis.description: Mandalay cobra — a regional cobra species with neurotoxic venom; medically important.
recommended_actions: Keep far away and observe safely
Call emergency services if bite occurs
first_aid: Keep bitten limb at neutral position
Naja mandalayensis.emergency: Immediate hospital attention for antivenom and supportive care.
Naja mandalayensis.fallback_protocol: Low confidence → treat as venomous and activate emergency pathway.

Ophiophagus hannah.description: King cobra — very large elapid with potent neurotoxic venom; highly dangerous.
recommended_actions: Do not attempt to approach or handle
Call wildlife control and emergency services
donts: Do not attempt capture or kill
Do not use tourniquets or cuts
Don't delay seeking medical care if bitten
first_aid: Transport rapidly to hospital for antivenom
Ophiophagus hannah.emergency: Immediate hospital transfer; antivenom and airway support may be needed.
Ophiophagus hannah.fallback_protocol: If uncertain → treat as highly dangerous; follow emergency first-aid and seek urgent care.

Do not allow patient to walk
Bungarus caeruleus.emergency: Immediate hospital evaluation; antivenom likely required.
Bungarus caeruleus.fallback_protocol: If confidence low → treat as highly dangerous and follow hospital referral.
